title-group.article-title: Enhanced Sensitivity to Tramadol in Diabetic Neuropathic Pain Compared to Nerve Compression Neuropathies: A Population PK/PD Model Analysis

aff.institution: University of Florida College of Pharmacy

aff.named-content: School of Medicine of Ribeirao Preto
School of Pharmaceutical Sciences of Ribeirao Preto

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Neuropathic pain, often associated with diabetic neuropathy or nerve compression injuries, arises from damage or dysfunction in the somatosensory nervous system. Tramadol, frequently prescribed for this pain, has its fraction unbound and that of its active metabolite (M1) significantly altered by diabetes. Yet, dosing adjustments for diabetic neuropathic pain remain underexplored. This study developed a comprehensive population pharmacokinetics/pharmacodynamics (PK/PD) model for tramadol and its major metabolites, focusing on diabetes's impact on PK and PK‐PD relationship to identify optimal dosing regimens. Data from patients with chronic neuropathic pain on oral tramadol were used to develop enantiomer‐specific population models, considering both total and unbound concentrations. Tramadol's PK was best described by a two‐compartment model with Weibull absorption and linear elimination and a one‐compartment model with enterohepatic circulation and first‐pass metabolism for the active M1. Simulations showed higher unbound fractions of the active M1 in patients with type 1 and type 2 diabetes. Despite a 67% and 14% reduction in the AUC of total (1R,2R)‐M1 in patients with type 1 and type 2 diabetes, respectively, the AUC of unbound (1R,2R)‐M1 remained consistent. The unbound concentration of the active M1 required to achieve 50% of the maximum pain reduction (IC50) was lower in patients with diabetes, indicating increased sensitivity to the drug. This model‐based approach provides valuable dosing guidance, suggesting once‐daily dosing treatments in patients with diabetes and twice‐daily dosing for patients with neuropathic pain secondary to nerve compression mechanisms.

fn.p: Funding: The clinical study was funded by Financiadora de Estudos e Projetos (FINEP, Grant 01.05.0948.00) and Fundação de Apoio ao Ensino e Assistência do HCFMRP‐USP (FAEPA). The data analysis and preparation of this article were performed independently of this grant.

list-item.p:
What is the current knowledge on the topic? ○
Neuropathic pain originates from lesions or dysfunction in the somatosensory nervous system due to various conditions, including diabetic neuropathy or nerve compression mechanisms.○
Despite the different pathophysiology associated with those conditions, dose recommendations do not differentiate based on the cause of neuropathic pain.

What question did this study address? ○
The present study aimed to characterize the effect of diabetes on tramadol pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics using a population approach, providing guidance for selecting effective doses for diabetic neuropathic pain.

What does this study add to our knowledge? ○
This study is the first comprehensive exploration of pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of both unbound and total tramadol, as well as its active metabolite, O‐desmethyl‐tramadol, in adult individuals with neuropathic pain, including those with or without diabetes.○
The study highlights the impact of diabetes on tramadol's pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, with diabetic patients exhibiting higher sensitivity to the drug.

How might this change drug discovery, development, and/or therapeutics? ○
Understanding the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of tramadol can guide clinical decision‐making for optimizing tramadol dose to different neuropathic pain conditions.○
These recommendations aim to enhance clinical practice and optimize the management of diabetic neuropathic pain.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Neuropathic pain arises from lesions or dysfunction in the somatosensory nervous system. Various conditions are associated with the onset of neuropathic pain, including metabolic disorders such as diabetic neuropathy, viral infections such as human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), leprosy, or post‐herpetic neuralgia, nerve compression damages (such as spinal cord injury, disc herniation, or amputation) as well as autoimmune disorders and inflammatory disorders. While some individuals experience mild symptoms, others suffer from incapacitating pain. Managing neuropathic pain often requires pain medications for effective relief. The pharmacological therapy for neuropathic pain includes gabapentinoids (i.e., gabapentin and pregabalin), tricyclic antidepressants, serotonin‐norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, and opioids such as tramadol and tapentadol [1, 2, 3]. Tramadol has demonstrated efficacy in reducing pain in diabetic peripheral neuropathy [4, 5]. However, its use can be limited by side effects such as nausea, constipation, and vomiting. While tramadol is typically recommended as a second‐line treatment, it may be considered first‐line in patients with acute pain exacerbations [4]. Although dose recommendations typically do not differentiate based on the cause of neuropathic pain [1], the underlying condition can potentially affect drug exposure or the exposure–response relationship.

Tramadol, a centrally acting analgesic, is commonly prescribed for the treatment of neuropathic pain due to its favorable efficacy and safety profile [2, 3]. It is available as a racemic mixture of (1R,2R)‐tramadol and (1S,2S)‐tramadol and effectively relieves moderate to severe pain through dual mechanisms: modulation of pain signal transmission via the μ‐opioid receptor and weak inhibition of norepinephrine and serotonin reuptake [6, 7]. Tramadol undergoes hepatic metabolism via CYP2D6, yielding O‐desmethyltramadol (M1), and via CYP3A4 and CYP2B6, yielding N‐desmethyltramadol (M2). Among its metabolites, M1 acts as a μ‐opioid receptor agonist. Notably, (1R,2R)‐M1 exhibits the highest μ‐opioid receptor affinity, which is primarily responsible for its analgesic effects [6, 8]. Its binding affinity to the μ‐opioid receptor (Ki = 3.4 nM) is significantly higher compared to that of racemic‐tramadol (Ki = 2.4 μM) and to (1S,2S)‐M1 (Ki = 240 nM) [6, 7, 8]. In fact, the pupillary response was significantly increased in CYP2D6 normal metabolizers compared to poor metabolizers, underscoring the critical role of CYP2D6 metabolism in tramadol's therapeutic efficacy [9]. Additionally, both O‐ and N‐demethylation of tramadol exhibit enantioselectivity [6]. Plasma concentrations at steady state for tramadol and M1 are typically reached within 2 days [10, 11].

Our previous research has demonstrated that diabetes significantly alters the fraction unbound (fu) and exposure to the active total (1R,2R)‐M1 [12]. However, it remains unclear whether diabetes could potentially change the pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) relationship for tramadol in neuropathic pain. The current recommended dosage for the effective management of pain related to diabetic neuropathy stands at an average of 210 mg per day [13, 14]. Clinical practice guidelines recommend initial daily doses of 50 mg, with a gradual titration using 50 mg dose increments, with a maximum daily dosage of 400 mg [2]. However, the evidence substantiating the dose recommendation of tramadol for managing diabetic neuropathic pain is limited, and there is a lack of PK/PD assessment for this indication. Given the escalating annual incidence of diabetes [15], it is essential to understand the impact of diabetes on the PK and PD of tramadol. Utilizing extensive clinical PK and PD data in patients with neuropathic pain secondary to diabetes or nerve compression mechanisms, our aim is to develop a population PK/PD model to characterize the exposure of tramadol and its major metabolites. We seek to assess whether diabetes changes the PK/PD relationship for tramadol. Furthermore, should a need for dose adjustment arise, our objective is to optimize tramadol dosing regimens tailored to diabetic neuropathic pain and neuropathic pain secondary to nerve compression mechanisms.

sec.title: Clinical Study
sec.p: This study is a secondary analysis of clinical data obtained in patients with chronic neuropathic pain for more than 3 months and pain scores rated above 40 out of 100 [12]. Written informed consent was obtained from each participant, and the study was approved by the local ethical institutional review board at the Hospital of the University of Sao Paulo, Brazil (1775/2008) and as exempt at the University of Florida (IRB202200717). In summary, all patients received a single oral dose of tramadol (100 mg, Tramal, Pfizer) after an 8‐h fasting period, accompanied by 200 mL of water. A standard meal was provided to all patients only 2 h after drug administration to avoid a food effect. Blood samples were collected before and up to 24 h after drug administration to analyze plasma concentrations of tramadol and its primary metabolites, O‐desmethyl tramadol, and N‐desmethyl tramadol, using a validated LC–MS/MS method [16]. The analytical method discriminated enantiomers and was applied to analyze total and unbound plasma concentrations, with the latter determined following an ultrafiltration step. The linear ranges and the lower limits of quantification for the bioanalytical method are provided in Table S1, Supporting Information. Pain scores were evaluated at baseline and at the same sampling times as in the PK study using a visual analog scale (VAS) on a 100 mm line, where patients marked their pain level, with 0 indicating “no pain” and 100 indicating “worst possible pain” (Figure S3, Supporting Information). Blood samples were also collected for various laboratory tests, including fasting blood glucose (FBG) level, hemoglobin A1C (HbA1C), serum creatinine, serum urea, albumin, aspartate transaminase (AST), and alanine transaminase (ALT). The glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) was calculated based on the CKD‐EPI Creatinine Equation (2021) [17]. Given the significance of the CYP2D6 enzyme in the formation of the active M1 metabolite, all patients underwent an assessment of the in vivo activity of CYP2D6 using metoprolol as a probe drug [18]. Following the administration of 100 mg of metoprolol (Lopressor, Novartis), urine samples were collected in the 0–8 h interval for the analysis of metoprolol and its metabolite α‐hydroxy metoprolol using a validated HPLC method with fluorescence detection [19]. The in vivo activity of CYP2D6 was expressed for each subject by the metabolic ratio of metoprolol/α‐hydroxy metoprolol (MRMet/OH‐met) in 0‐8 h urine samples [16].

sec.title: Pharmacokinetic Analysis
sec.p: A population PK model was developed using unbound and total plasma concentrations of each tramadol enantiomer and its primary metabolites, M1 and M2 (Figures S1 and S2, Supporting Information). Non‐linear mixed effect modeling using the First Order Conditional Estimation with Interaction (FOCE‐I) algorithm was implemented using NONMEM version 7.4.4 (Icon Development Solutions, Ellicott City, MD) and R version 4.4.1. A sequential approach was adopted in the model development process, wherein the PK parameters were fixed to their individual post hoc estimates. This systematic method involved addressing tramadol first, followed by M1 and M2 for each respective enantiomer. Plasma concentration data were converted into molar units to accommodate parent–metabolite conversion. The molar mass used for this conversion were 263.37 g/mol for tramadol and 249.35 g/mol for both O‐desmethyl‐tramadol and N‐desmethyl‐tramadol [20, 21, 22].

A defining feature of the parent–metabolite model is its simultaneous modeling of both unbound and total drug concentrations (Equation 1), enabling the estimation of the unbound fraction (fu).(1)Ctotal=Cunbound+Cbound=Cunbound+Kb∙Cunboundwhere Ctotal is the total drug concentration, Cunbound is the unbound drug concentration, Cbound is the protein‐bound concentration, and Kb is the binding proportionality constant (i.e., Cbound/Cunbound). It was assumed that protein binding exhibited linearity at therapeutic drug concentrations in the absence of a saturable mechanism [23], as represented by Equations (2) and (3):(2)fu=11+Kb (3)Ctotal=1fu∙Cunbound

Kb was estimated in the model, allowing the fu to be constrained between 0 and 1. Various delayed absorption models were explored to capture the initial delay and the lag of the absorption rate of tramadol, including first‐order input with or without a lag time and transit compartment model. To account for a time‐dependent absorption rate constant [kat] [24], a Weibull absorption which is a type of cumulative distribution function (cdf) was incorporated as follows (Equation 4):(4)kat=1−e−t−γβα,γ<t,α>1where α is a shape parameter, β is a scale parameter, and γ is a location parameter.

Two assumptions were made to address the identifiability issues associated with the metabolites. First, leveraging the data observed in rats [25], allometric weight scaling was applied to obtain the volume of distribution of M1 in humans. The allometric weight exponent was fixed to 1.VcM1,t,humanF=VcM1,t,ratWThumanWTrat VcM1,u,human/F=VcM1,t,human/F∙1/fuM1,where VcM1,t,human/F is the typical apparent volume of distribution of total M1 in human, VcM1,u,human/F is the typical apparent unbound volume of distribution of M1 in human, VcM1,t,rat is the volume of distribution of total M1 in rat, WThuman is the average total body weight of human, and WTrat is the average total body weight of rat. The values used in the calculations were as follows: VcR−M1,t,rat=0.1L,VcS−M1,t,rat=0.255L,WThuman=72.2kg, WTrat=0.235kg. Secondly, based on the published literature, it is known that an average of 30% of tramadol dose is eliminated by renal excretion as unchanged drug. Thus, the proportion of apparent unbound drug clearance from the central compartment of tramadol (CLotheru/F) was fixed to 0.3 [26, 27].

Pharmacokinetic parameters associated with the random effect were assumed to be log‐normally distributed. Ultimately, a pharmacokinetic parameter was defined as:θij=θi∙expηij,where θij is the ith parameter for j patient; θi is the population parameter estimate; and ηij is the deviation from the population mean for ith parameter for j patient such that ηi~N0ωi2. Residual error was modeled using a proportional error applied to concentrations for tramadol, M1, and M2 enantiomers as defined below:Yij=Fij∙1+εij,prop,where Yij and Fij are the observed and model predicted concentrations, respectively, for subject i and time j and εij,prop are the proportional residual errors for subject i and time j such thatεij,prop∼N0σprop2.

sec.title: Pharmacodynamic Analysis
sec.p: Pain score observations were recorded using a VAS within a range of 0–100 mm, where a score of 0 represented no pain and 100 mm indicated the worst pain. However, for analytical purposes and to facilitate constraints, we standardized the data to a range between 0 and 1. Given that (1R,2R)‐M1 is the active metabolite, and efficacy is associated with the unbound drug concentrations at the site of action, we utilized the predicted unbound concentration of (1R,2R)‐M1 to establish a relationship with the PD endpoint. The effectiveness variable, VAS pain score, was treated as a continuous variable. The concentration–effect relationship was described using an inhibitory E max PD model with an effect compartment to account for delay, as follows (Equations 5 and 6):(5)dCeffdt=ke0∙Cp,ij−Ce,ij (6)PDij=PD0i∙1−Imax,i∙Ce,ijIC50,i+Ce,ijwhere ke0 represents the delay relative to the plasma concentration by a first‐order rate constant, Cp,ij represents the predicted apparent unbound concentration of (1R,2R)‐M1 in the ith subject at the jth time point, Ce,ij is the apparent unbound (1R,2R)‐M1 concentration in the effect compartment in the ith subject at the jth time point, PD0i represents the baseline pain score value using VAS when no drug is present at time t=0 for i individual, Imax,i is the maximum fraction of treatment effect of tramadol in ith subject, and IC50,i is the concentration (nmol/L) at half of the maximal drug effect. Because both pain score observation and the individual prediction should be constrained between 0 and 1, a logit‐transformation was applied to efficacy estimation as follows (Equation 7):(7)Yij=explnλij1−λij+εij,add1+explnλij1−λij+εij,add,0≤Yij≤1where Yij represents the observed value for individual i at timej, and λij represents the predicted efficacy for individual i at time j, and εij,add is the residual error such that εij,add∼N0,σadd2. Additionally, considering that the estimations for Imax and PD0 must fall within the range of 0 to 1, and recognizing that the predictions of these continuous parameters could potentially extend to infinity, a logit‐transformation was applied to these parameters [28]. An additive IIV was used on the logit scale as follows (Equation 8):(8)θi=explntvθi1−tvθi+ηi1+explntvθi1−tvθi+ηi,0≤θi≤1where θi represents the parameter Imax or PD0 for individual i, tvθi was fixed effect (typical value of parameter) for individual i, and ηi is the deviation from the population mean for individual i such that ηi~N0ω2.

sec.title: Covariate Analysis
sec.p: Upon establishing a foundational parent–metabolite joint model, demographic and clinical variables were tested as potential covariates, including age, sex, body mass index (BMI), FBG level, HbA1C, serum creatinine, urea level, albumin, AST, ALT, CYP2D6 in vivo activity, CYP3A4 in vivo activity, and CYP2B6 genotype. All observations were complete, with no missing data for any covariates. After evaluating the additive linear model, the proportional linear model, and the power model, a power function was selected for continuous covariates, as represented by Equation (9):(9)θ=θtv∙CovCovmedβ

Here, θ represents the population parameter, Cov represents the covariate value, θtv is the typical value with a standardized covariate value of Covmed, and β is the power coefficient describing covariate parameter relationship. Standardized values of the covariates were the values regarded as reference in the general population. Reference values were median value 26.045 kg/m2 for BMI and median value 0.610 for CYP2D6 in vivo activity.

For categorial variable diabetes, proportional linear model was used as represented by Equation (10):(10)θi=βi∙θref,i=T1DMorT2DMwhere θi represents the population parameter for patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) or type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM), θref represents the population parameter for the reference group, patients without diabetes, and βi represents the covariate effect coefficient.

Both visual and numerical methods were employed to screen significant covariates. Scatter plots were used to visualize the relationship between covariates and parameters for continuous variables, while box plots were used to compare these variables across groups. The −2 log‐likelihood (−2LL) was computed to compare nested models. A p‐value of less than 0.05 indicated statistical significance for the inclusion of covariates in the model. A univariate covariate and stepwise covariate analysis were tested. For the stepwise addition, a significance level of 0.05 was employed for forward selection, while a significance level of 0.01 was used for the backward deletion of covariates from the full final model.

sec.title: Model Evaluation
sec.p: Model evaluation was conducted through various approaches to assess its suitability and performance. Goodness of fit (GOF) plots were used as an indicator of suitability, including the representation of model‐based individual predictions and population predictions versus the observed concentration. Visual predictive check (VPC) was constructed using the 5th, 50th, and 95th percentiles of the observed data to evaluate the simulation prediction. In addition, a non‐parametric bootstrap analysis of 500 simulations was conducted to verify parameter estimates [23, 28].

sec.title: Simulation of Exposure and Response
sec.p: Using the developed PK/PD model, simulations of exposure to tramadol and its main metabolites and pain scores were conducted for a comprehensive comparison across different groups based on significant covariates. Model simulations were performed using a virtual population of 500 subjects. Drug exposure was assessed using the area under the plasma concentration–time curve from 0 to 24 h (AUC0‐24). Median values and 95% confidence intervals (95% CI) were calculated when comparing exposures. For the response simulation, pain scores were normalized by baseline following steady‐state tramadol treatment. Additionally, simulations of different dosing scenarios were performed with escalating doses from 50 mg to the maximum daily dosage of 400 mg. The percentage of subjects experiencing substantial pain relief (> 50% reduction from baseline pain score) and moderate pain relief (30%–50% reduction from baseline pain score) was recorded. Pain relief was assessed at the time of maximum pain attenuation following a single dose as well as at trough concentrations 72 h after multiple dose treatment to characterize the sustained pain relief effect [29, 30, 31]. This investigation aimed to explore optimal dosing regimens for tramadol across various patient populations. All simulations were conducted using R Studio and the rxode2 package.

sec.title: Data
sec.p: The dataset included 30 patients with 2145 observations of PK concentrations, encompassing total and unbound concentrations of tramadol, M1, and M2 enantiomers, and 27 patients with 402 observations of PD endpoints. The descriptive statistics of demographics and clinical characteristics are shown in Table S2. The cohort had an approximately equal distribution of men (n = 14, 46.7%) and women (n = 16, 53.3%), with an age range of 19 and 59 years and a BMI range of 17.2 and 38.9 kg/m2.

sec.title: Pharmacokinetic/Pharmacodynamic Analysis
sec.p: The PK of both (1R,2R)‐ and (1S,2S)‐tramadol were best described by a two‐compartment model with Weibull absorption and linear elimination (Step 1, Figure 1; Table S3). A one‐compartment model with linear formation and linear elimination characterized both unbound and total concentration data for (1R,2R)‐ and (1S,2S)‐M1 (Table S4), with individual post hoc parameter estimates from Step 1. Furthermore, incorporating the first‐pass metabolism improved the fit of the first‐time point observation of the metabolite M1. While tramadol is known to undergo a 20%–30% first‐pass effect [10], our model estimated the proportion of first‐pass effect (fp) at 6% specifically for the M1 metabolite, suggesting that first‐pass metabolism may generate other metabolites in addition to M1. To capture the multiple secondary peaks observed in the M1 plasma concentration profile (Figure 2), an enterohepatic circulation process was implemented in the M1 model by adding a bile compartment. The inclusion of enterohepatic circulation is attributed to the conjugation of M1 with glucuronic acid to form M1‐glucuronides, which are excreted in bile and urine in rats [32]. Furthermore, exposure to the active M1 is significantly reduced in bile duct‐ligated rats in a perfused rat liver model [33], suggesting that enterohepatic circulation plays a significant role in M1 exposure.

caption.p: Sequential population PK/PD model for total and unbound concentrations of (1R,2R)‐tramadol and its metabolites (1R,2R)‐O‐desmethyltramadol (M1) and (1R,2R)‐N‐desmethyltramadol (M2) and (1S,2S)‐tramadol and its metabolites (1S,2S)‐O‐desmethyltramadol (M1) and (1S,2S)‐N‐desmethyltramadol (M2). The PK model consists of a two‐compartment model for unbound tramadol with a central compartment (apparent volume Vcparent,u/F) and a peripheral compartment (Vpparent,u/F) with the Weibull absorption model [fraction (1‐fp) and time‐dependent absorption rate constant (ka)]. Total and unbound plasma concentrations were simultaneous modeled to estimate the fraction unbound (fu) assuming that binding to plasma protein is linear. A one‐compartment model was used to describe M1 total and unbound plasma concentrations (volumes VcM1,u/F and VcM1,t/F). The M1 metabolite formation was modeled using the linear elimination from the parent compound [fraction of M1 creation (fm1) and formation clearance (CLFM1,u/F)] and the model accounted for first‐pass metabolism [fraction (fp) and rate constant Kmet1] and enterohepatic circulation [bile volume (VbileM1,u/F), clearance for bile excretion of unbound M1 (CLbileu/F), and the release rate constant from gall bladder (krelu)]. Unbound concentrations of M2 were described using a one‐compartment model (volume VcM1,u/F), and linear elimination (CLM2,u/F). M2 formation from the parent compound central compartment was modeled using Michaelis–Menten kinetics (rate constant Km and maximum velocity Vmax). Pain score data was best described using inhibitory Emax model (Imax,IC50, PD0) with effect compartment to capture the delay (ke0). Individual predicted unbound concentration of (1R,2R)‐M1 was linked to effect compartment.

Predicted correction Visual Predictive Check (PcVPC) plots for the final model for unbound (1R,2R)‐tramadol (a), total (1R,2R)‐tramadol (b), unbound (1R,2R)‐M1 (c), total (1R,2R)‐M1 (d), and unbound (1R,2R)‐M2 (e) models after a single oral administration of 100 mg rac‐tramadol in non‐diabetic patients with neuropathic pain (n = 12), and in patients with diabetic neuropathic pain with T1DM (n = 9) and T2DM (n = 9). Visual Predictive Check plot for pain score PD model (f). Open circles represent prediction‐corrected observed concentrations. Blue bins represent a simulation‐based 95% CI for 5th and 95th prediction percentiles of prediction‐corrected concentrations, whereas red bin represents a simulation‐based 95% CI for 50th prediction percentiles of prediction‐corrected concentrations. Black dashed lines represent the observed 5th and 95th percentiles of prediction‐corrected concentrations of 500 simulated data, whereas the black line represents the observed 50th percentile of prediction‐corrected concentrations of 500 simulated data. T1DM, type 1 diabetes mellitus; T2DM, type 2 diabetes mellitus.

sec.p: The estimated apparent central and peripheral volume of distributions of (1R,2R)‐tramadol and (1S,2S)‐tramadol, 439 [L] and 465 [L], respectively, were similar, indicating that enantioselectivity does not affect the distribution phase. The apparent central volume of distribution of unbound tramadol was affected by BMI for both enantiomers. This finding can be attributed to the high lipophilicity of tramadol, with a logP of 2.7 [34]. Tramadol is primarily metabolized to M1 by CYP2D6 [12, 35]. The clearance for the formation of M1 was approximately two‐fold higher for (1S,2S)‐tramadol compared to (1R,2R)‐tramadol, suggesting that CYP2D6‐mediated metabolism favors the formation of (1S,2S)‐M1, confirming previous observations in healthy volunteers [36]. Covariate analysis identified CYP2D6 in vivo activity as a significant factor influencing the apparent clearance for the formation of unbound M1, showing a positive relationship.

Though it is not pharmacologically active, the M2 metabolite contributes to the excretion of around 10% of tramadol dose in human urine [37]. Our analysis estimated the fraction of tramadol converted to (1R,2R)‐M2 to be 10% for and (1S,2S)‐M2 to be 22.5% (Table 1; Figure S17). The unbound concentrations of (1R,2R)‐ and (1S,2S)‐M2 were best described by a one‐compartment model with non‐linear formation and linear elimination, using individual post hoc parameter estimates from Steps 1 and 2 (Step 3, Table S5). As M2 is further metabolized to N,O‐desmethyltramadol (M5) via CYP2D6 [35], CYP2D6 activity was tested as a covariate for the apparent clearance of unbound M2. The inclusion of CYP2D6 successfully captured the large interindividual variability in M2 exposure, confirming the relevance of CYP2D6 activity not only for M1 but also for M2.

caption.p: Parameter estimates for final population PK/PD model of tramadol, O‐desmethyl tramadol (M1), N‐desmethyl tramadol (M2), and pain score.

fn.p: Abbreviations: ω2, Interindividual variability; σ2, Residual error variability.

sec.p: Diabetes was identified as a significant categorical covariate affecting the fu of tramadol and M1 (Table 1, Figure 1). Patients with T1DM and T2DM exhibited a higher fu of M1 compared to non‐diabetic and T2DM patients. Since the investigated subjects with diabetes had poor glycemic control with median (min‐max) HbA1C levels of 10.7 (8%–15.7%), the increased fu can be attributed to the high glucose levels, which may displace drugs from plasma protein binding sites [33]. Furthermore, simulations following 100 mg single dose administration of 500 subjects across diabetes groups were conducted. The AUC of total (1R,2R)‐tramadol and total (1R,2R)‐M1 were 67% and 14% reduced for T1DM and T2DM patients respectively compared to non‐diabetic patients (Figure 3). Also, simulation analysis demonstrated that the unbound fractions of tramadol and M1 in both enantiomers were higher in participants with both type 1 and type 2 diabetes (Figure 4). Despite the discrepancies in fu of tramadol and M1 in both enantiomers, exposure to the unbound μ‐opioid agonist (1R,2R)‐M1 remained unchanged in subjects with T1DM nor T2DM (Figure 3).

caption.p: Effect of diabetes on exposure (AUC0‐24 and C max) of unbound and total (1R,2R)‐ tramadol and the active (1R,2R)‐M1 following the administration of 100 mg tramadol single dose. Simulations were carried out in 500 subjects for each group, which were defined as subjects with T1DM and T2DM and subjects without diabetes. Results are presented as ratios of median (blue circle) along with 95% CI (horizontal lines) assuming subjects without diabetes as reference. The shadowed area represents 20% difference from the reference. For this simulation, other significant covariates, including BMI and CYP2D6 in vivo activity and in the model were set to median values. 95% CI for median were calculated using the following equation, nq±z0.975nq1−q,q=0.5, z0.975=1.96. T1DM, type 1 diabetes mellitus; T2DM, type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Simulated fraction unbound for (1R,2R)‐tramadol and metabolite (1R,2R)‐O‐desmethyltramadol (M1) and (1S,2S)‐tramadol and (1S,2S)‐O‐desmethyltramadol (M1) across different diabetes groups (n = 500), following the administration of 100 mg tramadol single dose.

sec.p: Our assessment identified 3 patients as non‐responders to a single dose of tramadol regarding pain score reduction within this cohort (more details on data exclusion criteria are provided in the Supporting Information). Since a delay in the PD response was observed respective to the plasma concentrations of the active unbound (1R,2R)‐M1 (Supp Material, Figure S2), an Imax model with an effect compartment was used to describe the PK/PD relationship (Figure 1, Table 1). Further details on parameter estimates, GOF plots, and VPCs are provided in the Supporting Information (Figures S5–S17; Tables S3–S5). The unbound concentration of (1R,2R)‐M1 required to achieve 50% of the maximum pain reduction (IC50) was estimated at 2.91 [nmol/L] for patients without diabetes, which corresponds to 725.61 ng/L. Diabetes was identified as a significant categorical covariate on IC50, signifying that patients with both T1DM and T2DM showed increased sensitivity to the drug (Table 1). The IC50 for T1DM was estimated at 0.156 [nmol/L] and for T2DM at 0.515 [nmol/L]. As a consequence, subjects with neuropathic pain due to nerve compression mechanisms experience lower response rates if treated with similar doses as patients with diabetic neuropathic pain (Figure 5).

caption.p: Median of pain reduction of simulated 500 subjects across different diabetes groups throughout 3 days following the administration of 50, 100, 200, and 400 mg tramadol at Q24h and Q12h dosing frequencies; (a) non‐diabetic group (q.d.), (b) non‐diabetic group (b.i.d.), (c) T1DM (q.d.), (d) T1DM (b.i.d.), (e) T2DM (q.d.), and (f) T2DM (b.i.d.). The pain scores of each individual were normalized by their baseline values. T1DM, type 1 diabetes mellitus; T2DM, type 2 diabetes mellitus.

sec.title: Simulations
sec.p: Recognizing the diabetes effect on tramadol PK and PD, the developed PK‐PD link model was employed to simulate novel dosing strategies for tramadol. Dose escalation simulations revealed that at the lowest dose of 50 mg once daily, sustained pain relief was substantial only for 22.4% in patients with neuropathic pain secondary to nerve compression mechanisms. However, this percentage increased to 61% for patients with T1DM and 51% for patients with T2DM. This difference is attributed to diabetes affecting tramadol's IC50 in neuropathic pain, with diabetic neuropathic pain being more responsive to tramadol than neuropathic pain secondary to radicular compression and median nerve compression. Our simulations suggest that a daily dose of 100 mg (q.d.) can alleviate neuropathic pain in over 80% of patients with T1DM or T2DM, considering both substantial and moderate responses. However, the same dosing regimen resulted in a lower response in patients with neuropathic pain secondary to nerve compression mechanisms. Specifically, our simulations showed that 43% of patients experienced substantial pain relief, while 23% responded with moderate pain relief. Interestingly, patients with neuropathic pain secondary to nerve compression mechanisms benefit more from a twice‐daily dosing regimen. Simulations using 100 mg twice daily resulted in over 80% of responders in this subgroup.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: A comprehensive population PK/PD link model was developed to account for tramadol enantiomers and their primary metabolites, M1 and M2, in patients with neuropathic pain from various causes. The model accounts for the complex PK of tramadol, including specific parameter estimates for each enantiomer resulting from the enantioselective pharmacokinetics [6, 7], first‐pass metabolism, plasma protein binding and unbound drug concentration, and enterohepatic circulation for M1 metabolite [10]. The pain attenuation response was linked to the unbound concentrations of the active (1R,2R)‐M1 metabolite using an effect compartment to account for the delay between exposure and response. Our results demonstrated a superior analgesic effect of tramadol in diabetic neuropathic pain (T1DM and T2DM) compared to neuropathic pain secondary to radicular compression and median nerve compression. Our simulations indicated that over 80% of patients with neuropathic pain secondary to diabetes are likely to respond to a once‐daily dose of 100 mg of tramadol, most of them with substantial pain attenuation at 72‐h, defined as a 50% reduction in baseline pain score (Table 2). However, patients with neuropathic pain due to nerve compression mechanisms are more likely to respond to twice‐daily administration of tramadol. For instance, 83% of responders are expected with 100 mg dose every 12 h, compared to 64% and 76.4% of responders following 100 mg and 200 mg once daily (Table 2).

caption.p: Percentage of subjects achieving substantial or moderate pain relief across groups without diabetes, T1DM and T2DM.

fn.p: Note: Substantial pain relief is defined as > 50% reduction from baseline score, while moderate pain relief is defined as a 30%–50% reduction from baseline score. Pain scores were assessed at the point of maximum pain relief and immediately before the next dose in a steady state condition (sustained pain relief evaluation).
Abbreviations: T1DM, type 1 diabetes; T2DM, type 2 diabetes.

sec.p: The PK/PD model developed in this study provides valuable insights into tramadol PK and PD in treating chronic neuropathic pain. Diabetes can affect drug absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination in many ways [38]. Regarding protein binding, in vivo albumin glycation can displace the drug from its binding sites, increasing the fraction of the drug accessible for crossing membranes, reaching the target tissue or the eliminating organs, or being filtered in the glomerulus [33]. This is particularly important in patients with diabetes with poor glycemic control, such as in this particular cohort. Our findings indicate that despite the increased fu of (1R,2R)‐M1 in patients with T1DM, no differences were observed in the AUC of unbound active (1R,2R)‐M1 comparing patients with or without diabetes. This observation can be attributed to tramadol's low‐hepatic extraction status [32], suggesting that clinically relevant effects due to alterations in plasma protein binding are unlikely [39].

Tramadol is commonly administered to treat neuropathic pain [40], including diabetic neuropathic pain [13], which occurs in approximately 16% of patients diagnosed with diabetes [36]. Interestingly, tramadol exhibits a hypoglycemic effect in patients with T2DM [41]. The mechanism involves the activation of a neuronal insulin signaling cascade, specifically by increasing the expression of insulin receptor substrate‐2. This activation was suppressed by the opioid antagonist naloxone and dexamethasone [41]. Also, tramadol's impact on glucose metabolism extends beyond the central nervous system. In diabetic rats lacking insulin, activating mu‐opioid receptors by tramadol enhances glucose utilization and reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis, ultimately lowering plasma glucose levels [42]. Consequently, tramadol ameliorates peripheral glucose metabolism by activating mu‐opioid receptors, highlighting the interconnectedness of central and peripheral glucose regulation [41].

Our data indicate that individuals with diabetes‐induced neuropathic pain exhibit higher sensitivity to tramadol, as evidenced by the reduced IC50. The study shows that similar sustained pain reduction is achieved when patients with nerve compression‐related neuropathic pain receive 200 mg q.d., while those with diabetes‐induced neuropathic pain receive 50 mg q.d. Additionally, patients with diabetes may benefit from once‐daily dosing of tramadol. In contrast, patients without diabetes may require a twice‐daily dosing to achieve sufficient sustained pain reduction. A similar behavior was previously described for pregabalin, since patients with diabetic neuropathy showed higher response rates than patients with central pain and fibromyalgia, indicating that different neuropathic pain conditions should be treated separately [43].

High blood sugar levels can damage blood vessels and nerves over time [44, 45]. In diabetic neuropathy, hyperglycemia initiates pathogenic changes, including post‐translational protein modifications by glucose, increased glucose metabolism via aldose reductase and glycolysis, and other catabolic pathways. Interestingly, peripheral nerves contain insulin receptors that mediate the neurotrophic and neuro‐supportive effects of insulin, independent of systemic glucose regulation [46, 47]. The enhanced analgesic action following tramadol dosing likely results from its hypoglycemic effect and modulation of peripheral insulin receptors, ultimately ameliorating nociceptive fiber damage in diabetic neuropathy. In contrast, neuropathy due to compression (e.g., carpal tunnel syndrome and disc herniation) involves marked changes in intraneural microcirculation, nerve fiber structure, impaired axonal transport, and alterations in vascular permeability, leading to edema formation and nerve function deterioration [48].

Our findings indicate that increasing tramadol doses or frequency in T1DM and T2DM does not result in additional pain relief once the maximum effect is reached in diabetic patients. Numerous reports have highlighted significant adverse events associated with tramadol, particularly at higher doses. These adverse effects include dizziness, constipation, nausea, headache, and somnolence [1]. Additionally, high doses of tramadol induced fluctuations in blood glucose levels representing a potential side effect that has not received adequate attention. Such alterations in glucose levels could contribute to the likelihood of seizures in patients receiving high doses of tramadol [49].

In summary, our model‐based PK/PD link approach offers valuable guidance for prescribers managing neuropathic chronic pain. For patients with diabetic neuropathic pain, a low IC50 value supports the efficacy of once‐daily dosing treatments. Conversely, patients with neuropathic pain secondary to nerve compression mechanisms, such as cervical or lumbar disc herniation and carpal tunnel syndrome, may require more frequent dosing, such as twice‐daily dosing, to counteract lower sensitivity to tramadol. In both scenarios, dose titration is essential to prevent unnecessary high doses typically associated with adverse events. Despite the useful insights for clinical practice, our study has some limitations. Firstly, patients presenting vomiting following tramadol dosing (n = 8 in a total of 38 patients, or 21% of all investigated patients) were excluded from the PK and PD analysis due to the drug loss, impairing both PK and PD assessments. This exclusion may have introduced bias in the response rates for this cohort. Additionally, three patients were identified as non‐responders based on PD data and excluded from the PD assessment. Secondly, the use of allometric scaling may introduce some bias in parameter estimation. Furthermore, the clinical data used to build the model does not include information on long‐term tramadol use, preventing an assessment of its prolonged effects. Tolerance to tramadol with extended use could result in a diminished response or necessitate higher doses for similar efficacy [15]. Our current model does not account for tolerance mechanisms. Additionally, although pain was assessed using the VAS pain score, it was evaluated over 24 h, which may have introduced variability in pain score records due to changes in patient alertness and mindset throughout the day. Despite these limitations, our study provides a detailed time course of pain scores, allowing for a comprehensive assessment of pain changes over time.

sec.p: D.C., P.M., S.G., B.C., G.R.L, V.L.L., V.V., and N.M. wrote the manuscript. D.C., P.M., S.G., G.R.L, V.L.L., V.V., and N.M. designed the research. D.C., P.M., S.G., B.C., G.R.L, V.L.L., V.V., and N.M. performed the research. D.C., P.M., S.G., V.V., and N.M. analyzed the data.

sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.
